articles.headline: House’s Anti-Semitism Resolution Exposes Generational Fight Over Ilhan Omar
articles.snippet: The House’s Democratic leadership, responding to statements by Representative Ilhan Omar deemed hurtful to Jews, will put to a vote a resolution condemning anti-Semitism.
articles.abstract: The House’s Democratic leadership, responding to statements by Representative Ilhan Omar deemed hurtful to Jews, will put to a vote a resolution condemning anti-Semitism.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A formal condemnation of anti-Semitism that is up for a vote in the House this week has touched off a furious debate between older House Democrats and their young liberal colleagues over whether Representative Ilhan Omar is being singled out for unfair treatment over her statements on Israel.

articles.headline: A Tornado Warning Gave Alabamians 12 Minutes to Prepare. 23 People Died Anyway.
articles.snippet: A warning for the ferocious tornado was issued quickly. But in a place with widespread poverty and few places to hide, it could not save everyone.
articles.abstract: A warning for the ferocious tornado was issued quickly. But in a place with widespread poverty and few places to hide, it could not save everyone.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEAUREGARD, Ala. — Becky Boyd’s phone alerted her on Sunday afternoon that a tornado was imminent, but she didn’t think much of it. Warnings had come before, and nothing had happened.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder, Patricia Mazzei and Audra Melton

articles.headline: Companies Falsely Labeled Products ‘Made in U.S.A.’ Their Financial Penalty? $0.
articles.snippet: Democrats are questioning why firms that manufactured products in China but claimed they were American-made did not get tougher punishment from the Federal Trade Commission.
articles.abstract: Democrats are questioning why firms that manufactured products in China but claimed they were American-made did not get tougher punishment from the Federal Trade Commission.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Patriot Puck, a New York-based company, wrapped its hockey pucks in American flags, declaring them “The Only American Made Hockey Puck!”

articles.headline: Border at ‘Breaking Point’ as More Than 76,000 Unauthorized Migrants Cross in a Month
articles.snippet: The number of migrants apprehended on the southwest border is up about 90 percent from levels recorded at the same time last year, the authorities said.
articles.abstract: The number of migrants apprehended on the southwest border is up about 90 percent from levels recorded at the same time last year, the authorities said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The number of migrant families crossing the southwest border has once again broken records, with unauthorized entries nearly double what they were a year ago, suggesting that the Trump administration’s aggressive policies have not discouraged new migration to the United States.

articles.headline: Michael Bloomberg Will Not Run for President in 2020
articles.snippet: The billionaire former New York City mayor said he would not seek the presidency, avoiding a crowded primary field that is generally to the left of him.
articles.abstract: The billionaire former New York City mayor said he would not seek the presidency, avoiding a crowded primary field that is generally to the left of him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg, the former New York City mayor who joined the Democratic Party last year to crusade against President Trump, announced he would not seek the White House himself in 2020, discarding plans to mount a maverick campaign that would have tested the party’s openness to a wealthy centrist with a chameleon-like approach to partisan politics.

articles.headline: Genoa Bridge Collapse Throws Harsh Light on Benettons’ Highway Billions
articles.snippet: Autostrade, a privatized road operator, dwarfs the Italian family’s fashion empire. It’s now facing angry questions about big profits and lax regulation.
articles.abstract: Autostrade, a privatized road operator, dwarfs the Italian family’s fashion empire. It’s now facing angry questions about big profits and lax regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENOA, Italy — Long before the Morandi Bridge collapsed in Genoa, Italy, last year, killing 43 people, an economics professor named Marco Ponti took aim at the private company that managed the structure, raising two fundamental concerns.
articles.byline: By David Segal and Gaia Pianigiani

articles.headline: In the Middle of His Official Business, Trump Took the Time to Send Checks to Michael Cohen
articles.snippet: The dates on newly available checks shed light on the parallel lives Mr. Trump was living — at once managing affairs of state while quietly paying the price of keeping his personal secrets.
articles.abstract: The dates on newly available checks shed light on the parallel lives Mr. Trump was living — at once managing affairs of state while quietly paying the price of keeping his personal secrets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a busy day at the White House, President Trump hosted senators to talk about tax cuts, accused a Democratic congresswoman of distorting his condolence call to a soldier’s widow and suffered another court defeat for his travel ban targeting Muslim countries.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: U.S. and E.U. Are Headed for a Food Fight Over Trade
articles.snippet: American negotiators insist that agriculture be included in a prospective trade deal while European officials say the topic was never up for discussion, jeopardizing talks before they even begin.
articles.abstract: American negotiators insist that agriculture be included in a prospective trade deal while European officials say the topic was never up for discussion, jeopardizing talks before they even begin.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a White House meeting last July, President Trump and Jean-Claude Juncker, the European Commission president, stepped into the Rose Garden and proclaimed they had a trade deal or, at the very least, the makings of a future pact.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Will Kim Jong-un Return to Brinkmanship? Weak Economy Is Forcing His Hand
articles.snippet: North Korea’s deepening economic trouble may propel it to return to the negotiating table — or resume weapons tests to force a deal.
articles.abstract: North Korea’s deepening economic trouble may propel it to return to the negotiating table — or resume weapons tests to force a deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — When the armored train carrying Kim Jong-un back from his summit meeting with President Trump in Vietnam reached Pyongyang Station at 3:08 a.m. Tuesday, throngs of flower-waving North Koreans greeted their leader with “boundless emotions and excitement,” the country’s state-run media said.

articles.headline: In Blow to Trump, America’s Trade Deficit in Goods Hits Record $891 Billion
articles.snippet: The president has railed against the trade deficit, but numbers from last year show that textbook economics caught up with some of his unorthodox economic policies.
articles.abstract: The president has railed against the trade deficit, but numbers from last year show that textbook economics caught up with some of his unorthodox economic policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — America’s trade deficit in goods with the rest of the world rose to its highest level in history last year as the United States imported a record number of products, including from China, widening the deficit to $891.3 billion and delivering a setback to President Trump’s goal of narrowing that gap.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Ana Swanson
